@OversightDems National Security Subcommittee hearing on Securing U.S. Election Infrastructure and Protecting Political Discourse is happening now. Watch it here:  http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=AglpcN5Dy0U …
If you care about the future of elections in our country like I do, I encourage you to watch the hearing here: https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCXSlyao4qkUFiPqghptHtZA …

The National Security Subcommittee of the Committee on Oversight and Reform will have a hearing on Wednesday at 1pm CT to examine our election system and how we can protect ourselves from interference, influence and attempts by foreign adversaries to undermine U.S. elections.
Tennessee needs to admit the risks to our elections and make immediate plans to start using the funds to update voting machines in every county.
Yet according to the Election Assistance Commission, TN still has about $35 million in unspent funds from the Help America Vote Act to purchase new voting equipment. And we've had it for 18 years!

I'm glad that the Davidson County Election Commission voted in favor of purchasing voting machines that produce a voter-verified paper audit trail, but as of August 2018 only 14 of the 95 counties in Tennessee used voting systems with a paper trail.
The election system in Knox county has already been hacked. Election results weren’t altered then, but what about next time?
The heads of the CIA, the Defense Intelligence Agency, the FBI and the National Security Agency have all said that foreign adversaries are trying to influence U.S. elections.
Without a paper trail, it’s almost impossible to determine if an election system has been hacked.
Because most counties in Tennessee still use electronic voting machines that do not produce a paper trail, our elections are some of the most vulnerable in the U.S.
If you don’t already know the story about state Representative Harry T. Burn and his mother, read more about it here: https://bit.ly/2zWCcGu

Nashville is full of civil rights leaders and @FISK1866 alum Diane Nash is a living legend. I encourage everyone to watch the Freedom Riders movie and visit the Civil Rights Room at the downtown @NowatNPL to learn about her role during this important time in history.

Bigotry and hatred have no place in Tennessee or anywhere else in America. It's good the Equality Act passed the House, and I hope the Senate has the courage to bring it to the floor for a vote. Every American should be guaranteed equal protection under the law.
https://cooper.house.gov/media-center/press-releases/cooper-cosponsors-election-security-bill …
I'm proud that Metro Nashville has taken the necessary steps to start using voting machines that produce a voter verifiable paper audit trail. The rest of the state needs to follow suit.
Paper ballots are one of the most important ways to make our elections more secure.

The news this week that Russia successfully hacked into the voting system in two counties in Florida reinforces what the majority of our national security and intelligence experts have said – that foreign adversaries have been trying to influence U.S. elections.

Tennessee should expand Medicaid so we can insure MORE Tennesseans, help our rural hospitals, and lower costs for everyone. I hope @GovBillLee will consider the serious risks to our state before signing this bill.
It is unrealistic to expect it to help Tennesseans; in fact, it threatens coverage for our most vulnerable citizens. There is a reason no other state is doing this.
Converting to a Medicaid block grant is not what our state needs to improve health outcomes and combat rising costs. https://wapo.st/2Yz97um

I have known Alice Rivlin for many years. She was a titan, and one of our nation’s greatest budget leaders. Alice put policy over politics and did what was right to get America back on track fiscally. She was the real deal.

Charlie's long-standing service to Metro government and dedication as a board member to many nonprofits has left an indelible mark on the Nashville community.
Charlie Cardwell was an honorable man and a deeply committed public servant. He and his wife, Marie, who left us only 10 weeks ago, will both be greatly missed.

Thank you @mayorbriley and Davidson County Election Commission for your leadership. I hope that the Metro Council will approve this expense as part of their final budget so Nashville can help lead Tennessee in securing our elections.
National security experts agree that paper trails are essential to ensuring the protection of our elections.
I'm pleased to see that the proposed 2020 Metro budget includes funding for new voting machines that produce a voter verifiable paper audit trail. https://nyti.ms/2BVnP7D
Senate Republicans need to stand up to President Trump and protect those who need insurance the most.
Today I voted to protect the 2 million Tennesseans with pre-existing conditions from President Trump’s latest attempt to take away their health care coverage. We cannot allow that to happen.
Thankfully it seems state legislators on both sides care about Tennessee’s reputation and are calling for change.

Fine local reporting by @NC5PhilWilliams and others begs the question: Why would any African American, person of color, woman – or any decent man, woman or child – feel safe or respected under Rep. Casada’s Speakership?

Almost every other nation is committed to working together to save the planet. Why isn't the United States?
I was proud to cosponsor the Climate Action Now Act that passed the House last week. Pulling out of the Paris Agreement was a shortsighted and selfish act by the Trump administration.
It is clear that human action is negatively impacting the environment. We must act soon to limit the damage we're causing before it's too late. https://nyti.ms/2LrzqAY

I’m disappointed that @GovBillLee signed the voter suppression bill, but we can’t give up. We must continue working toward a TN where all eligible voters are registered to vote and are regularly participating in our political system. Our state and our nation depend on it.

President Trump’s request to strike down the ACA is cruel and irresponsible. If his request is granted, more than 2 million Tennesseans with pre-existing conditions risk losing their health coverage – with no alternative plan and no other options. Is that really what we want?
